senses.de: To show something clearly by giving evidence or proof.
senses.ex: They demonstrated the effectiveness of the strategy by sharing their sales result.

Tips.title: Clarity is Key
Tips.description: Use 'demonstrate' when you need to make something very clear through examples or evidence.
Tips.example: The study demonstrated the drug's benefits through extensive trials.

Tips.title: Strength of Argument
Tips.description: The word is often used when presenting a strong argument or case in writing or speech.
Tips.example: Her essay demonstrated how the policy might cause more harm than good.

Tips.title: Evidence-Based
Tips.description: It implies that you have logical reasons or factual evidence for the point you're making.
Tips.example: They demonstrated the solution's effectiveness with data from recent tests.

senses.de: To explain or teach by showing.
senses.ex: The teacher demonstrated the experiment in front of the class.

Tips.title: Learning by Showing
Tips.description: Used when someone is teaching by actively showing how things are done, not just telling.
Tips.example: The chef demonstrated slicing techniques during the cooking class.

Tips.title: Visual Aid
Tips.description: Often used when visual elements are involved in explaining something.
Tips.example: The scientist used a model to demonstrate how the molecule was structured.

senses.de: To protest or express your opinion in a public way.
senses.ex: Thousands of people took to the streets to demonstrate against racism.

Tips.title: Public Stance
Tips.description: Use it when referring to taking a public stand on issues, often in groups.
Tips.example: Activists will demonstrate for climate action this weekend.

Tips.title: Active Engagement
Tips.description: Implies an active effort to show support or disagreement, beyond just voicing it.
Tips.example: The workers demonstrated outside the factory for fair wages.

senses.de: To show and explain how a machine or piece of equipment works.
senses.ex: The salesman demonstrated how to operate the new vacuum cleaner.

Tips.title: Practical Use
Tips.description: Connects to showing practical usage and operation of tools, software, or machinery.
Tips.example: The technician demonstrated the new software's functions during the webinar.

Tips.title: Hands-On Learning
Tips.description: Suggests an interactive approach to learning how something works by direct involvement.
Tips.example: He demonstrated how to edit photos by letting us try during the workshop.

Display.wordDefinition:
Display means to show something in a way that it can be seen or noticed. For example, a store may display its products in the front window to attract customers.

In simpler terms, demonstrate is used when you want to prove or show how something works or is done, while display is used when you want to show something off or make it visible to others.

Exhibit.wordDefinition:
Exhibit means to show or display something, such as a piece of art in a museum.

In general terms, demonstrate is used more in the context of showing how something works, while exhibit is more used for showing something off.

Express.wordDefinition:
Express means to convey feelings, thoughts, or ideas through words, actions, or art. This is usually applicable when you want to communicate something that comes from within, such as emotions or creativity.

In simple words, demonstrate is used to show evidence or prove a point, while express is used to communicate emotions or ideas through language or art.

Indicate.wordDefinition: Indicate means to point out, suggest, or show something with signs or signals. It is applicable in situations where you want to indicate the location of something or point out a particular fact.

Manifest.wordDefinition:
Manifest means to make something clear or visible through its actions, appearance or effects.

For example, someone might demonstrate how to solve a math problem by showing their work and explaining each step. A person's frustration might manifest itself in their tone of voice or body language, even if they don't explicitly express it verbally.

Present.wordDefinition:
Present means to show or offer something to others.

This word is applicable when you want to give a speech or show something to other people, such as presenting a project in front of a class.

For example, you might present a PowerPoint presentation about a historical figure.

The difference between the words demonstrate and present is that demonstrate is about showing or proving something, while present is about offering or showing something to others.

Prove.wordDefinition:
Demonstrate means to show or provide evidence for something, while prove means to establish the truth or validity of something by presenting evidence or facts.

For example, you might demonstrate how to solve a math problem by going through the steps on a whiteboard, but you would then have to prove that your answer is indeed correct by showing your work.

Reveal.wordDefinition:
Reveal means to show or make something known that was previously hidden or unknown.

It is used when you want to disclose a secret or uncover something. For example, a detective can reveal the identity of a criminal.

To summarize, demonstrate is used to explain or teach whereas reveal is used to uncover or disclose.

Show.wordDefinition:
Both the words demonstrate and show mean to provide evidence or proof of something.

Show is more commonly used when you are displaying or revealing something physical or observable. For example, a friend might ask to see a picture of your new dog, and you would show them the picture.

You would use demonstrate when trying to prove a concept or method, and show when displaying something physical or observable.
